reviewText:
How to make a game hard artificially?

1.Ignore design flaws or
2.integrate some more of them in your game,
3.combine it with a poor level design and there you have it.

I don't know where to start, everything feels wrong about this game.
Bad controls, bad graphics, ugly design. The idea sounds not that bad, but it is executed so bad.
Not even the leveldesign is well done.
If you want to make a game, that tests your reflexes, the game should allow you to respond quickly.
Guess what? It doesn't.
Even the annoying pop-up window apearing after each death on a level has to be clicked away with the mouse every single try.

This game is a challenge, but not one that is worth a try.
The game is hard, but a hard game needs clever design to motivate me to play it.
Maybe I have missed the clue in this game, but all these flaws have made me so mad.

reviewText:
3d-puzzle game, performing as a degraded version of Marble Madness - just as the first chapter did - but now with additional challenge of colours, which works as the keys of some kind. So you move a cube via some 3d obstacles, and switch its colours - otherways the next block on your path won't let you move forward.

What I liked there is noticable better work of designer with the Unity engine. It is still flawed too much - but I'll give them a point for a progress. I also liked some of the backgrounds, the artwork is strange to look at, but not awful. Even decent sometimes. So after some levels it almost felt like I'm touring inside someone's mind... weird, but fun feeling.

What I didn't liked is the aggressive tone of the game - like hey! I'm hardcore here
date: move aside!" - which in my eyes is not add up with such type of gameplay. Like a thin pimply teenager wearing leather and spikes and pretending he's the 1%-biker there.\n\nOverall
recommended: it is one of those games
hoursPlayed: where you really need to be on the same channel with its developer
voteText: otherwise you'll just not get the idea where and how this piece of code is presumed to be entertaining. I tried to like it myself
helpfulPercent: as I do enjoy puzzle-games and platformers... but alas! It is even worse than the first game
votesHelpful: by the terms of fun out of the gameplay.\nMy mark is 4/10. Funny try for a new indie developer
votesTotal: but I wouldn't pay for it."

reviewText:
Aggravating for the wrong reasons

Cons:
Menu buttons are pretty unresponsive
Stock unity physics can be quite wonky and random at times. This would be fine if it wasn't the primary gameplay mechanic.
Camera is complete trash. It can rotate, but if you do then you won't be able to see where your cube thing is.
The menu that pops up at the start of most levels introducing new mechanics is incredibly annoying. Every time you die, you have to take your hand off the controller or keyboard, head over to your mouse, close the window, then you can finally start the level again. Why can't it be closed by keyboard?
Changing between the light/color modes is too slow and unresponsive.Pros:
Cards?
Has potential to be entertaining.

reviewText: Why So Evil 2: Dystopia adds a few new mechanics from the first game, but overall makes the game so much less rewarding, and more frustrating. One of these new mechanics is changing the colour of your cube to the colour of the corresponding platform you are trying to move onto. Sure this isn't a bad idea, but combined with horrid, unresponsive controls, and this game is truly flawed. When you have to be super ninja fast about changing the colour of the cube to the platforms or they fall, the game fails to respond in time, horrible. The levels themselves are usually uninventive and ugly, and the soundtrack is the last thing they need. Especially the shutdown initiated" every time you fall
date: WTF? Sure this game is challenging
recommended: but the overall game is just executed so badly that this challenge is not worth it. If its on sale and you want a game you'll play for 15 minutes before you ragequit
voteText: 5 bucks cannot be justified with what this game delivers

reviewText:
I Ragequit on level 9.

I guess it kept its promise?


Now Serious :

In this game you try to get your cube to the finish. The main problem with this is that you cannot turn your camera and you can only use WASD to move your cube around. This means that you only have 8 directions you can guide your cube to. If this wasnt enough, in this game you have a cube that bounces of its edges. This sometimes results in you pressing W to go forward but your cube actually just jumps of the platform because it got stuck on a corner. This wouldn't be too bad if you would be allowed to turn your camera so you could work around that.

reviewText:
The game does what it promises.
It does test your reflexes and your ability to manage your strategies in order to beat levels. Some of the levels are easier than others but it all depends on how patient and quick you are with buttons.
It DOES make me wanna smash my keyboard violently after 100th termination" but I keep my cool and I do not give this game the satisfaction of yelling out its title in desperate and violent act of rage.

This game really does a well job at testing your limits and not to mention those achivments do look nice when you unlock one of them.
To not give this game a try would really be an opportunity missed. Me and my girlfriend played the game just to try it now and we quite liked the challange and the competition it created :D. We'll surely play it more!

This game certanly did deserve a spot in my Steam Library!"

reviewText:
I bought this game when it was on sale, being a fan of puzzle games and all. (And the pretty colors got me convinced, lol.)

I played it for a few minutes, and...I tried to like it. But it wasn't fun, just really frustrating. I didn't even stick around long enough to get trading cards because it was that frustrating.

Cons:

- Controls take a long time to respond. (And this is with my comp exceeding the min specs.)

- The movement of the cube is random. When you press W, will it slide forward or will it bump off the platform you're on? It's a mystery!

- The camera is all wonky. Like everything else, it takes a long time to respond and on top of that, you have to keep an eye on the cube as well.

- SHUTDOWN INITIATED. SHUTDOWN INITIATED. SHUTDOWN INITIATED. (Repeat about 50 times, and you get the idea.)

Pros:

- I learned the word pulchritudinous"."

reviewerDisplayName: ALT+F4 to see my real name
reviewText:
As if we needed a sequel to Why So Evil; a game that I eviscerated and exposed for its poor mechanics and general rushedness. Unfortunately, the same idiotic and completely inept developers are at it again. Going into this, I expected more of the same rushed and rage-provoking gameplay, with maybe some change in perspective or design. But not rage-provoking because of any challening level design; because of sheer lack of effort in the controls and physics department. This delivered.

Where do I start? The addition of an adjustable camera was a noble idea; however, it was terribly executed. The camera is in a fixed position, not set on the block you play as. You CAN turn the camera; except that when you do, you just look off into the foggy abyss. You cannot change your angle so you can effectively see the forecoming floors in front of you. So, what was even the point of adding the camera?

It can also be pretty difficult to determine the difference between red and pink when you have to be quick. It is possible that this was done to add to the rage game" asthetic; but if so
date: that begs the question: Do bad game mechanics make a rage game? No
recommended: they don't. Plenty of games have successfully labelled themselves as rage games that do not use being a bad game as an excuse for being a rage game.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: this is pretty much the same tomfoolery we got from the previous installement; except worse because they didn't learn their lesson from the last game. This might have been a nice experiment for your college game development class
voteText: but it does not make a nice Steam game; and the developers are morons for thinking otherwise.\n\nScore: 3/10 - Very Poor"

reviewText:
Product received for free

The sequel to Why So Evil hit the store over a year ago.

Now the game is relatively simple, the puzzle consists of two squares, the Alt and the Tab. Your job is to press both of them at the same time while in game and wait for the cards to drop. Now the shape might differ depending what keyboard you have.

The game was also given for free in a giveaway a few months later. By free i mean a nice 10k keys that you were guaranteed to receive one if you managed to catch it. But it doesn't matter, another one was made like a few weeks later. And then another one... and another one. This is like my 3rd account where i'm farming its cards.

The game is only a bribing tool for people to advertise their steam groups and sites so that they can get a bigger audience by giving them free keys of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• games with cards to farm, and unfortunately this was one of them.

reviewText:
(This game was provided by Grabthegames.com .  Thanks, guys!)

Why so mean?  Why so crude?
Why so angry? Why so rude?


....Why so evil?  I said it once before, I'll say it again.  I LOATHE Unity.  AVGN has his LJN,  I have Unity.  Best part about Unity games?  They uninstall.


The first 4 levels are a breeze, after that, you'll regret being a cube with little control and awkward controls.  It's good to stop on spot as a cube.   However, rolling as a cube....is limited.  Like I said, you'll feel okay with it for about 4 levels, before things get rough.  Timing between color change and landing on the tile (namely a falling tile) is terrible and it won't register correctly.

I managed to survive to like...level 7 before quitting.  Spinning blades that insta-kill while you're on falling platforms iof the wrong color?  That's my limit.  After that, I spent 2 hours idling for the cards.

If you're into puzzle stuff, have at it.  If you see it on a giveaway, feel free to grab it.  Otherwise, avoid it.


1/10     No more Unity....please.....

reviewText:

reviewText: My whole life was nothing but sadness and darkness. But today that's all over. I found happiness for the cheap price of 4.99$. I could have spend that money on food and water to survive for 1 more day, but nahhh that's for dirty peasants. This game's perfection is beyond a human's mind. While playing this amazing masterpiece, with it's unbelivebly touching and deep story that left me in tears for 6 hours straight. I thought to myself I should change my life to the better. NO more days as a dirty unworthy peasant. In the last 20 hours since this game came out I managed to get a girlfriend, marry her, make 2 kids, get a dog, and a job in Mc‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ingDonalds. Thank you Why so Evil 2: Dystopia developers you changed my life!

reviewText:
The first one wasn't good enough, so the second should try to fix what was wrong. But it failed. If you're reading this you problably know what the first game was like, so let's go for the changes:

-Now you can move the camera, but the rotantion isn't focused on the player, so it's almost useless.
-They changed the menu's design, the Unity's default design was better though.
-The levels don't have themes anymore, now you always plays in a space background on platforms with ugly textures.
-The levels aren't as well developed as in the first game.
-Less traps and more psicodelic color shifting platforms, that's not an improvement.

This game may be usefull for exercising your brain in a boring way or for testing your patience, but it doesn't challenge your abilities, it'll ignore then and request a new level of the human mind.

reviewText: Why So Evil 2 is a decided improvement on the original.  Sadly, it still isn't much good.\n\nTo the credit of WSE2, the silly back to level one" mechanic has been dropped. and a new
date: tight-in follow camera makes the experience a little more intense.  The graphics are a bit flashier.  There's also a new mechanism of having to press a key corresponding to the colour of the next tile you want to move on.\n\nYou still control a cube that lurches and rolls awkwardly around the playing field.  Helpfully
hoursPlayed: the game allows your WASD control to take precedence over physics when the cube balances on the edge of a platform.  Achievements have been added (in game only -- they were apprarently once tied to Steam Achievements that have since been removed) but I cannot see the full list as it goes out of frame (I'm running in windowed mode.  Perhaps they would be visible in full screen mode; they don't interest me enough to bother trying.)\n\nThe camera can be rotated with the mouse.  I advise against using this
voteText: however
helpfulPercent: as your cube will never be quite properly centered on the screen afterwards until you die or make it to the next level.\n\nThere still isn't very much game here though.  You roll around some platforms
votesTotal: avoid some moving obstacles and get to the exit gate.  The game suffers from a lack of refinement
commentsCount: and a lack of inspiration.  However tragic your personal circumstances may be
column16: I guarantee that you do have something better you could be doing with your life than playing this dull semblance of a game."

reviewText: It has some advantages from the predecessor game. The first game is very simple and plays a bit clunky, this one has some advantages and some new ideas that really makes it a whole new game. The physics can still be strange and the cube can move too damn fast, but the game is cheap (again) and can play very well, with some time of fun in it. Buy it when in sale, preferably.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I do NOT reccomend this game, you have to either use your dominate hand for a controll, mine being switching colors, or have to use one hand to move AND switch numbers, 2 levels I've played make this even worse a layout, one where walls of color are moving towards you, okay cool, BUT THE WHOLE WORLD IS MOVING AND THE PLATFORMS AREN'T. So you have to roll to try to stay on your platform AND change colors, after you've completed THAT train wreck, you find that you have to switch to a color, because if you arne't the color of that platform it will FALL, okay that was fine in a regular course, HOW ABOUT ON FULL OF THEM WHERE THERE ARE SEVERAL WALLS MOVING BACK AND FORTH OUT OF SYNC. And to add to that furustration, you basically have to roll constantly or the walls WILL get you, but if you roll constantly your cube will start to move diagonally and flip out and change speeds, which means you have little to no way to survive, as the whole board is random colors, so you have no chance. It's a good concept, horribly excecuted, even for less than 50 cents I do not reccomend. Unless you love being mad at stuff.

reviewText: I have no idea why I'm playing this. The gameplay is annoying, the controls are the textbook definition of clunky, the story is nonexistant, the collision detection makes blocks drop way before I've actually landed on them...this is just not a good game. I honestly can't put it any other way.

reviewText:
Review is for both games (Why So Evil and Why So Evil 2)
I took both games from giveaways. I thought it could be relaxing flash game, made with Unity. Unity is a good start I could say. Ok, now the review:

ThingReviewMenuIn 1st part of game I could say there is no menu, you jump straight into the game. In 2nd part of the game menu is more improoved, much easier to choose what you want. But, when you press New Game" button (haven't tried other buttons except "Load Game")
date: you have to wait couple of seconds to load the game. If you press "Load Game" button
recommended: level's number will appear so you could choose level. It's more interesting I think...LauncherThere isn't much to say about launcher of the 1st part of game
hoursPlayed: but 2nd part of the game's launcher is... Weird... I could say...? Take a look at it[prntscr.com]. Could someone translate me some words?PhysicsWell
voteText: the physics of game are terrible
helpfulPercent: not finished. I haven't played 1st part so much
votesHelpful: so I will talk about 2nd part. In 2nd level of 2nd part of the game there is moving plate
commentsCount: you have to manually walk where the plate moves
column16: I couldn't even complete that level. Next thing I could say
column17: when you fell off the plate
column20: it takes some seconds to restart
column21: since you fell little long.Controls1st part of the game had better controls
column24: it felt block is easy. In 2nd part of game it felt block is hard and it was hard to move it
column25: especially when the plates are connected with angles.\nMy final verdict - some people say "Game eats so much ram memory"
column26: what I say "Game eats so much nerves"."
